newsitem.title: GERMANY: Volkswagen restarts talks on new jobs.
newsitem.headline: Volkswagen restarts talks on new jobs.

text.p: Wage talks for some 90,000 staff at German car-maker Volkswagen AG restarted on Wednesday amid optimism for an agreement on the number of new posts to be created in line with expected output increases.

Previous talks between VW and the IG Metall metal and engineering sector trade union broke down as union officials said employers were unwilling to give assurances on the number of jobs to be created.
Volkswagen has earlier said that strong demand for the new version of its Passat saloon may mean adding about 400 jobs at its plant in Emden. VW's work council is seeking at least 1,000 new posts.
"We are in agreement with VW over (the need for 400 new jobs)," IG Metall chief negotiator Juergen Peters told reporters, adding that VW now agreed in principle that further jobs could follow.
He did not give an overall figure for the number of jobs that could be created.

VW has said it might shift surplus workers from its Wolfsburg plant to Emden to help boost annual production in the sought-after updated saloon to some 400,000 units. That possibility has however been rejected by the works council.
The negotiations are also due to cover proposals for a scheme that would allow early retirement for VW workers.
